channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: First Look At New $26 Billion Opioid Settlement
item.description: Johnson & Johnson, a drug manufacturer accused of downplaying the addictiveness of opioids in its marketing, would shell out $5 billion over nine years. Drug overdose deaths rose nearly 30% in the US last year, to a record of 93,331.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Olympics Opening Ceremony on Friday and How Brew Readers Are Feeling About It
item.description: In a poll of 6,000 Morning Brew readers, 42% said they’re less likely to watch the Tokyo Olympics than previous years’ Olympics. And 51% said they’re worried that the Olympics will be a superspreader event.  Covid: Should the Olympics have been canceled this year due to Covid-19 concerns? Viewership: How much of the Olympics do readers plan to watch?
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 22
item.description: . Stat: US life expectancy fell by 1.5 years in 2020, the steepest drop since World War II, thanks in large part to the coronavirus. (New Yorker)  Read: Does CrossFit have a future?
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: France Starts Mandating Vaccination for Entry to Cultural Venues
item.description: The US federal government hasn’t introduced any vaccine requirements for businesses, and it likely won’t take any steps until the FDA grants full approval to at least one of the shots. The vaccine strategy has resulted in two things:It has angered a lot of people: More than 100,000 protestors hit the streets last weekend, saying the vaccine rules infringed on their rights.   Bottom line: From $1 million lotteries to calling in Olivia Rodrigo for a PSA, US officials have offered loads of carrots to push the vaccine-hesitant to get their shots.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Venmo Gets Rid of Its Public Feed
item.description: Venmo is getting rid of its public feed as part of a larger app redesign that’ll roll out over the next few weeks. The FTC cited that feature, among others, in a complaint against Venmo that was settled back in 2018.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 21
item.description: Victoria’s Secret CEO Martin Waters discussed the company’s shortcomings as it plans to split from parent L Brands on August 3.  Quote: “We got it wrong.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Backlash in Israel Following Ben & Jerry's Decision to Ban Sales in Occupied Territories
item.description: What happened: Ben & Jerry’s said on Monday it wouldn’t renew its contract with its licensee in Israel that distributes ice cream in Israeli-occupied territories because it was “inconsistent with our values.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Netflix Moves Into Video Games As Subscription Growth Slows
item.description: Bottom line: Heated competition from Disney+ and a lack of popular new shows is causing Netflix to sweat. “We view gaming as a new content category for us,” the company said. Netflix confirmed rumors it’s jumping into the gaming industry.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: So the Billionaires Went to Space. Now What?
item.description: In its big report on the space industry, Morgan Stanley identified the 10 drivers of a space economy that could grow to $1 trillion by 2040. Reality check: While space tourism news has gotten the recent buzz, it’s just a small slice of the overall space market, which is currently dominated by SpaceX. After he landed yesterday, Bezos said sales for private seats on Blue Origin flights (two more of which are planned for this year) are already approaching $100 million. Now that Bezos and Richard Branson have both completed their flights, what’s next for the space tourism industry?
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Netflix Moves Into Video Games As Subscription Growth Slows
item.description: Netflix confirmed rumors it’s jumping into the gaming industry.  Key takeaways: The company added 1.5 million new subscribers, slightly better than its 1M estimate.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Venmo Gets Rid of Its Public Feed
item.description: Venmo is getting rid of its public feed as part of a larger app redesign that’ll roll out over the next few weeks. The FTC cited that feature, among others, in a complaint against Venmo that was settled back in 2018.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Backlash in Israel Following Ben & Jerry's Decision to Ban Sales in Occupied Territories
item.description: What happened: Ben & Jerry’s said on Monday it wouldn’t renew its contract with its licensee in Israel that distributes ice cream in Israeli-occupied territories because it was “inconsistent with our values.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 21
item.description: Victoria’s Secret CEO Martin Waters discussed the company’s shortcomings as it plans to split from parent L Brands on August 3.  Quote: “We got it wrong.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: So the Billionaires Went to Space. Now What?
item.description: After he landed yesterday, Bezos said sales for private seats on Blue Origin flights (two more of which are planned for this year) are already approaching $100 million. Now that Bezos and Richard Branson have both completed their flights, what’s next for the space tourism industry? Space tourism is just one of 10 drivers of the space economy that Morgan Stanley reported.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Volkswagen Is Phasing Out Sales of Passat in the US
item.description: Volkswagen said it will stop selling its Passat model in the US next year as automakers pivot to SUV production. Automakers have sent several US sedan models to the junkyard in recent years, including the Chevy Impala, Ford Focus, Dodge Dart, and Chrysler 200.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 20
item.description: (Will Hoenig) Read: What is going on with Covid right now. Just wait until they find Mare of Easttown... That means calling the TV → telly, cookies → biscuits, and gas station → petrol station.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Companies Announce IPO Plans Despite Market Sell-off
item.description: Universal Music Group: Billionaire investor Bill Ackman’s SPAC scrapped its complex deal to buy a 10% stake in UMG, which is home to artists like Taylor Swift, after the SEC squashed the idea.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Preview of Blue Origin’s First Passenger Space Flight
item.description: Jeff Bezos’s space company, Blue Origin, will launch its first human test flight at 9am ET from the small desert town of Van Horn, Texas. + The latest from Gossip Brew: While Virgin Galactic's Richard Branson might have beat Bezos to space by 10 days, he only reached an altitude of 53.5 miles.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Pandemic Recession Was the Shortest Ever
item.description: The pandemic-induced recession lasted only two months, from February 2020 to April 2020, making it the shortest recession in US history. Zoom out: The Covid-19 recession ended an economic boom that began in June 2009 and lasted 128 months, the longest US economic expansion on record.  The US government is certainly acting like the recession is long gone. Let's start the clock again. The federal eviction moratorium ends on July 31.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Preview of Blue Origin’s First Passenger Space Flight
item.description: Jeff Bezos’s space company, Blue Origin, will launch its first human test flight at 9am ET from Van Horn, Texas, a small desert town. Today’s flight is expected to reach 62 miles in altitude and pass the Kármán line, the invisible boundary to outer space.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Pandemic Recession Was the Shortest Ever
item.description: Big Picture: The start of the pandemic recession also marked the end of the US’ longest-ever economic expansion streak that started in June 2009. The pandemic-induced recession lasted only two months, from February 2020 to April 2020, making it the shortest recession in US history. The US government is certainly acting like the recession is over.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Volkswagen Is Phasing Out Sales of Passat in the US
item.description: Automakers have sent several US sedan models to the junkyard in recent years, including the Chevy Impala, Ford Focus, Dodge Dart, and Chrysler 200.   Bloomberg has called the death of the sedan “the biggest car trend of the decade.”
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Companies Announce IPO Plans Despite Market Sell-off
item.description: Universal Music Group: Billionaire investor Bill Ackman’s SPAC scrapped its complex deal to buy a 10% stake in UMG, which is home to artists like Taylor Swift, after the SEC squashed the idea.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 20
item.description: Stat: Authorities in Malaysia put 1,069 seized bitcoin mining rigs worth $1.26 million in a police parking lot and proceeded to crush them with a steamroller last week. (Will Hoenig) Read: What is going on with Covid right now.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: July 19
item.description: Bezos in space: Jeff Bezos will blast off to space in a Blue Origin rocket tomorrow, joined by a record-setting crew.   That’s everything else that matters.  Everything else: Ted Lasso season 2 hits Apple TV+ on Friday. Gonna be a fun one.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 19
item.description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel vowed to address climate change after touring the “surreal, ghostly” scene of a German village destroyed by flooding. (The Atlantic)  Read: The truth behind the Amazon mystery seeds.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Deepfakes in New Bourdain Doc Raise Questions Around AI Ethics in FIlm
item.description: Neville said he used the AI technique because it was “important to make Tony’s words come alive.”  Neville told GQ that he received permission to recreate Bourdain’s voice from Bourdain’s literary executor and his widow “just to make sure people were cool with that.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Report: NSO Group Software Used to Hack Journalists', Executives' Phones
item.description: One notable finding: Pegasus was reportedly used to hack the phone of someone in journalist Jamal Khashoggi's inner circle four days after he was murdered.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook and Biden in War of Words Over Vaccine Misinformation
item.description: The social media company pushed back on Saturday against increasing criticism from the White House that the company is allowing the spread of Covid-19 vaccine misinformation. More than 97% of new hospitalizations from the Delta variant are of people who’ve not been vaccinated, the agency said. “The fact is that vaccine acceptance among Facebook users in the US has increased,” the company wrote, citing a study that showed vaccine acceptance among FB users has jumped 10–15 percentage points since January.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Kriss Kross: Lego Action Figures
item.author: Mary Tobler

item.title: Report: NSO Group Software Used to Hack Journalists', Executives' Phones
item.description: One notable finding: Pegasus was reportedly used to hack the phone of someone in journalist Jamal Khashoggi's inner circle four days after he was murdered.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: July 19
item.description: Bezos in space: Jeff Bezos will blast off to space in a Blue Origin rocket tomorrow, joined by a record-setting crew.   That’s everything else that matters.  Everything else: Ted Lasso season 2 hits Apple TV+ on Friday. Gonna be a fun one.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Deepfakes in New Bourdain Doc Raise Questions Around AI Ethics in FIlm
item.description: Neville said he used the AI technique because it was “important to make Tony’s words come alive.” But Bourdain never said that.  Neville told GQ that he received permission to recreate Bourdain’s voice from Bourdain’s literary executor and his widow  “just to make sure people were cool with that.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 19
item.description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel vowed to address climate change after touring the “surreal, ghostly” scene of a German village destroyed by flooding. (The Atlantic)  Read: The truth behind the Amazon mystery seeds.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook and Biden in War of Words Over Vaccine Misinformation
item.description: Facebook has taken steps to limit the spread of vaccine misinformation—such as removing posts that promote vaccine lies—but the Biden administration thinks those actions have been toothless.   WH Press Secretary Jen Psaki said health misinformation on social media is “leading to people not taking the vaccine, and people are dying as a result.” More than 97% of new hospitalizations from the Delta variant are of people who’ve not been vaccinated, the agency said.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers With...NFL Legend Ndamukong Suh
item.description: It’s one of those things where I don't think you need to bet all of your money on one thing, but I do think you need to have exposure to it. I had to ask myself, “How do I understand what a budget is?” I remember back in the day a long snapper named Don Muhlbach was one of the few guys in the locker room I would talk to about finance, where he was at with his business, and who he aspired to be. Four sacks in a playoff game or a Super Bowl win—that’d be the best. Some of them I've already accomplished so that’s probably why I didn’t pick them.  No. 1 draft pick Trevor Lawrence is getting his signing bonus paid out in cryptocurrency.  There’s for sure more conversations on those topics in the locker room compared to 2010 when I first got in the league. I don’t see myself putting my salary fully into bitcoin. If you could own one building what would it be? Now, it’s on Reddit and you see all the news about GameStop so I think it’s seen as more “cool” to talk about it and be in the know.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Money Matters: How Many Credit Cards Is too Many?
item.description: Credit card rewards can pack a serious punch. —Eduardo from New YorkThe question isn’t how many credit cards you should have, but rather how much of your total credit limit you’re using. If you have just one credit card with a $1,000 limit, stay sub-$300, even when you pay in full and on time. How many credit cards should I have, and is it OK to close one if I never used it and have no balance?
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 17
item.description: 97% of people hospitalized due to Covid-19 are unvaccinated. CDC Director Rochelle Walensky said that the Delta variant is spreading quickly among unvaccinated people in the US.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Warns Companies on Rising Risks of Operating in Hong Kong
item.description: In a business advisory issued yesterday, the US government listed the threats US companies in Hong Kong might face:Electronic surveillance and compromised data securityRisks regarding transparency and access to critical business informationDeteriorating press freedomA new Chinese national security law that targets political dissidentsLooking ahead…the advisory won’t demand specific actions from private companies.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Secretary Yellen to Meet With Other US Regulators to Discuss Stablecoin
item.description: During next week’s meeting, Secretary Yellen and other regulators will ask themselves: If there is no oversight of these US dollar-backed coins, what does that mean for the OG US dollar? It’s a coin that is—in theory—more stable than other cryptocurrencies like bitcoin, ether, etc.
item.author: Matty Merritt
